timelineSections.title: Forced Relocation and Brutalization of Native Americans
timelineSections.headline: Forced Relocation and Brutalization of Native Americans

description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"President Andrew Jackson signed the Indian Removal Act in 1830. Throughout the 1830s, Native Americans were forcibly relocated from the Southeastern United States. In 1838,","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":" President Martin Van Buren deployed thousands of federal troops to expedite the removal process, forcing Native Americans off their land at bayonet-point.","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.history.com/topics/native-american-history/trail-of-tears"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" During this forced relocation, which would come to be known as the Trail of Tears, an estimated 5,000 Native Americans died of illness and profoundly inhumane conditions.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Tens of thousands of Native American children were ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://boardingschoolhealing.org/education/us-indian-boarding-school-history/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"removed from their families and sent to boarding schools run by churches and the federal government","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". The express intent of this policy of the United States government was to “reprogram” young Native American children by committing cultural genocide, erasing their religion, language and other millenia-old traditions. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Dennis Banks, George Mitchell, and Clyde Bellecourt collaborated with others to create the  American Indian Movement (AIM) and demand recognition of Native American sovereignty from the US government. Initial AIM actions included the occupation of Alcatraz in 1969, the Trail of Broken Treaties March and occupation of the Bureau of Indian Affairs in 1972, and the occupation of Wounded Knee in 1973. Local AIM related groups continue to advocate for Native American civil rights, self-determination, and resources today.


","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The first Native American Cabinet Secretary, Deb Haaland, announces a government-wide effort to search for the remains of Native American children forcibly relocated to schools around the country.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Beginning in 1865, white Southerners organized themselves into vigilante groups, such as the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ku Klux Klan","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/ideology/ku-klux-klan"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", to mobilize terror campaigns against Black people and hinder the progress of Reconstruction. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Lynchings","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://eji.org/reports/lynching-in-america/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", the extrajudicial executions of Black people by mobs of white people, were a widespread practice in the Jim Crow South. These shows of racial terror were often a public spectacle: the executions were gruesomely  violent and often performed in front of crowds of cheering participants. Lynchings, which killed thousands, were designed to terrorize Blacks and enforce their subordinate position in American society: often Black people were killed for perceived violations of the racial order. For decades, Southern politicians in Congress ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"refused to pass","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/05/us/politics/rand-paul-anti-lynching-bill-senate.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" federal legislation to protect Black people from racial violence.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Racial terror set off the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Great Migration","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/long-lasting-legacy-great-migration-180960118/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" of African Americans in the 20th century. Beginning in 1910, 6 million Black people moved from the South to Northern and Western cities fleeing racial terror and seeking economic opportunity.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"For two days in 1921, mobs of white people in Tulsa, Oklahoma rioted in the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Tulsa Race Massacre","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.okhistory.org/publications/enc/entry.php?entry=TU013"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", what is now known as the single worst incident of racial violence in the United States. White vigilantes killed between fifty and three hundred people, and destroyed thousands of homes and businesses in Black neighborhoods, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"including “Black Wall Street,”","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.history.com/news/black-wall-street-tulsa-race-massacre"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" a hub a Black economic activity at the time. The riot in Tulsa was just one of many similar race riots instigated by white mobs across the country, which devastated Black neighborhoods and businesses.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Thousands of African Americans gathered in Washington in a ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://washingtonareaspark.com/2013/02/06/before-1963-the-1922-silent-march-on-washington/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"silent protest","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" march, denouncing racial terror and urging the passage of a federal anti-lynching bill.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"On a vacation to visit his relatives in Mississippi, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Emmett Till","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/emmett-tills-casket-goes-to-the-smithsonian-144696940/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", a 14-year old Black boy, was brutally murdered by two white men for allegedly whistling at a white woman. An all-white jury acquitted the two men of his murder, catalyzing widespread indignation. His mother held Emmett’s funeral with an open casket, intentionally showing the world what the violence of racism had done to her child’s body.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

At this time, the American Psychological Association classified homosexuality as a ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"psychiatric disorder","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.nytimes.com/1973/12/16/archives/psychiatrists-in-a-shift-declare-homosexuality-no-mental-illness.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

timelineSections.title: The New Deal and Divestment from Black Communities
timelineSections.headline: The New Deal and Divestment from Black Communities

description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Following the financial devastation of the Great Depression, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt ushered in the “New Deal” with sweeping federal policies to combat poverty and spur the economy’s recovery. Major pieces of federal legislation, including the Social Security Act and the Agricultural Adjustment Act, were ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"designed to exclude Black people","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/28/books/review/when-affirmative-action-was-white-uncivil-rights.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", particularly Black farmers and domestic workers, from the new income security and wealth-building programs.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":" ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Redlining","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.npr.org/2017/05/03/526655831/a-forgotten-history-of-how-the-u-s-government-segregated-america"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", a critical policy of the New Deal-era Federal Housing Administration, perpetuated segregation and exacerbated the racial wealth gap. The federal government subsidized the development of segregated white suburbs and backed white homeownership while refusing to insure mortgages in or around African American neighborhoods. This enabled white homeowners to amass wealth and property while most Black families were shut out of this wealth creation.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In 1943, a brawl between hundreds of Black and white people erupted into a ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Race Riot in Detroit","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://detroithistorical.org/learn/encyclopedia-of-detroit/race-riot-1943"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". While the United States military fought racism abroad in WWII, tensions caused by systemic racism at home boiled over into violence, after African Americans endured decades of discrimination of employment, substandard living conditions, and police brutality. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"With the close of World War II, African Americans ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"continued to be excluded","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2014/06/the-case-for-reparations/361631/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" from social policy in the Servicemen’s Readjustment Act, commonly known as the GI Bill.  Black people were excluded from federally-backed low-interest home loans as well as federal education assistance. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"From 1955 to 1956, civil rights activists in Montgomery, Alabama led the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/montgomery-bus-boycott"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Montgomery Bus Boycott","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", a protest against the policy of racial segregation on the public transit system following the arrest of Rosa Parks. This 13-month mass boycott ended with a ruling from the Supreme Court that the segregation of public buses was unconstitutional.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

Board.","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In Little Rock, Arkansas, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"nine black students","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://nmaahc.si.edu/blog-post/little-rock-nine"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" attempted to integrate Little Rock High School. Then Arkansas Governor Orval Faubus","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"called in the state National Guard to block the school door, while a mob of angry white residents protested integration around the school building. The “Little Rock Nine” were only able to attend classes after President Eisenhower sent in federal troops to escort them inside the building.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

timelineSections.title: The Civil Rights Movement
timelineSections.headline: The Civil Rights Movement

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In the 1960s, a mass movement to vindicate the civil rights of African Americans swept across the nation. Through protests and non-violent direct action, civil rights activists exposed the brutality of white supremacy and won meaningful legislative and moral victories.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Beginning with the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.history.com/topics/black-history/the-greensboro-sit-in#:~:text=The%20Greensboro%20sit%2Din%20was,college%20towns%20throughout%20the%20South."},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"first sit-in at Woolworth’s in Greensboro, N.C.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", Black students protested segregation at lunch counters and other dining facilities across the South. These sit-ins led to the formation of the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://snccdigital.org/inside-sncc/the-story-of-sncc/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", which grew to mobilize a mass movement of young people in direct action across the country. At the same time, the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.britannica.com/topic/Southern-Christian-Leadership-Conference"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Southern Christian Leadership Conference","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", led by Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and other faith leaders, mobilized church congregations in non-violent activism.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"At a 1963 civil rights demonstration in Birmingham, Alabama –  a series of sit-ins and marches known as \"","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"http://www.pbs.org/black-culture/explore/civil-rights-movement-birmingham-campaign/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Project Confrontation","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"” –  white police officers unleashed dogs and fire hoses on non-violent protesters. Televised images of wanton brutality shifted the public narrative in favor of civil rights. Later that year, more than 200,000 people convened on the National Mall for the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/march-washington-jobs-and-freedom"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", where King delivered his famous “I Have a Dream” speech. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In response to the widespread activism, Congress passed the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.nps.gov/articles/civil-rights-act.htm#:~:text=The%20Civil%20Rights%20Act%20of,and%20the%20right%20to%20vote."},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Civil Rights Act","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"  which outlawed discrimination in employment and public segregation.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In 1965, civil rights activists planned a march from Selma to Montgomery in demand of voting rights for African Americans. In Selma, the activists were beaten by police  and an angry mob, as they attempted to cross Edmund Pettus Bridge, a brutal confrontation that came to be known as ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.blackpast.org/african-american-history/bloody-sunday-selma-alabama-march-7-1965/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Bloody Sunday","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". In response, that same year, Congress passed the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.justice.gov/crt/history-federal-voting-rights-laws"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Voting Rights Act","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", a federal guarantee of voting rights that eliminated discriminatory tests and established penalties for interfering with the ballot. \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In 1966, the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://nmaahc.si.edu/blog-post/black-panther-party-challenging-police-and-promoting-social-change"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Black Panther Party","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", a revolutionary black nationalist party advocating socialism and self-defense against white violence, was founded in Oakland, California. The Black Panthers advocated for Black power and self-determination and provided “survival programs” – such as health clinics and free breakfast programs – in Black communities.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In a raid orchestrated by the FBI and the Chicago police department, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"officers assassinated","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.history.com/news/black-panther-fred-hampton-killing"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" the leader of the Chicago Black Panthers, Fred Hampton. After initially accusing Hampton and his fellow Black Panthers of attempted murder of CPD officers, the FBI is forced to admit to a coordinated campaign to infiltrate and undermine the Chicago Black panthers. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

timelineSections.title: The War on Crime, the War on Drugs, and the Racialized Politics of Fear
timelineSections.headline: The War on Crime, the War on Drugs, and the Racialized Politics of Fear

description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Beginning in the 1960s, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"high-profile political leaders","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2015/10/the-black-family-in-the-age-of-mass-incarceration/403246/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" on both the right and the left used thinly veiled racial rhetoric to connect civil rights activism to rising street crime.  \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson declared a federal “","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"War on Crime","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://time.com/3746059/war-on-crime-history/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":",” an effort which flooded local law enforcement agencies with federal resources and primarily targeted Black urban neighborhoods. That same year, Congress passed the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Law Enforcement Assistance Act","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://time.com/3746059/war-on-crime-history/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", providing new grants to local police departments to purchase military-grade equipment and increase patrols in low-income communities of color. \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

slides.title: The Crime Control and Safe Streets Act

description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Congress ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"expanded","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://time.com/3746059/war-on-crime-history/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" its robust federal investments in local policing with the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act. These federal programs had catastrophic consequences for Black communities. As historian Elizabeth Hinton writes, “Federal grants were ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"tied to","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://time.com/3746059/war-on-crime-history/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" arrest rates, encouraging more apprehensions in those neighborhoods that had been explicitly targeted for special law-enforcement programs.”\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In his successful 1968 presidential campaigns, President Nixon used inflammatory rhetoric about crime and racist appeals as part of his infamous “","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Southern Strategy","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2019/07/26/what-we-get-wrong-about-southern-strategy/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"” to win votes from white people in the South. In a sharp turn towards “law and order” politics, Nixon drew associations between civil rights activism and crime, inciting racist fears about urban unrest.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Building on Johnson’s War on Crime and the punitive policies that followed, Nixon formally declared a federal “","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"War on Drugs","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://drugpolicy.org/issues/brief-history-drug-war"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"” in 1971. This campaign was designed to combat drug use and abuse through increased criminalization and harsh punishment. Nixon’s administration ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"intentionally targeted","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://drugpolicy.org/issues/brief-history-drug-war"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" left-leaning people (who were associated with drug use in liberal counter-cultures) and Black people with policing and jailing for drug offenses.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In 1973, Nixon established the Drug Enforcement Administration, increasing the scope and power of federal drug control. The number of individuals incarcerated for drug offenses ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"skyrocketed","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://drugpolicy.org/issues/brief-history-drug-war"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" in the years to come.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"After deeming all existing death penalty statutes unconstitutional in 1972 in ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Furman v. Georgia","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", the United States Supreme court upheld capital punishment in 1976. In ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Gregg v. Georgia","marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/428/153/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", the Court ruled that punishment of death under Georgia’s death penalty statute did not violate the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments. After a national hiatus, the death penalty resumed in several, primarily Southern, states. Following ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Gregg","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", the American death penalty became ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"almost exclusively","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.themarshallproject.org/2016/03/30/it-s-been-40-years-since-the-supreme-court-tried-to-fix-the-death-penalty-here-s-why-it-failed"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" a Southern phenomenon: since 1976, more than 80% of executions have been carried out by Southern states. \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.oyez.org/cases/1960/236"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Mapp v. Ohio","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" established that law enforcement needed a warrant before conducting a search.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.uscourts.gov/educational-resources/educational-activities/facts-and-case-summary-gideon-v-wainwright"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Gideon v. Wainwright","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", the Court guaranteed the right of criminal defendants to a lawyer, regardless of their ability to pay for counsel.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Supreme Court ruled in ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.oyez.org/cases/1963/615"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Escobedo v. Illinois","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that defendants must be allowed to consult with their attorneys during police interrogations.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"1966:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":" ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.oyez.org/cases/1965/759"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Miranda v. Arizona","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":" ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"established that police must inform defendants of their rights prior to police questioning (commonly referred to as the “Miranda Rights”).\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

timelineSections.title: Draconian Sentencing Reforms at the Federal and State Level
timelineSections.headline: Draconian Sentencing Reforms at the Federal and State Level

description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"New York Governor Nelson Rockefeller established harsh prison sentences for drug offenses, including for possession of small amounts of drugs. These “","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Rockefeller Drug Laws","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://drugpolicy.org/sites/default/files/FactSheet_NY_Background%20on%20RDL%20Reforms.pdf"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"” became the “national policy model” for the War on Drugs. Many states and Congress followed suit with harsh drug sentencing legislation in the years to come.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In 1984, Congress passed draconian federal sentencing guidelines with the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Sentencing Reform Act","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.everycrsreport.com/reports/RL32766.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". The bill strictly curtailed discretion in sentencing in the federal system, creating a Sentencing Commission which would establish sentencing guidelines. The bill also abolished federal parole and declared that “rehabilitation” was no longer a goal of federal criminal-legal punishment. \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Congress authorized vast asset forfeiture and seizure by local law enforcement agencies with the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Comprehensive Crime Control Act","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.congress.gov/bill/98th-congress/senate-bill/1762"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". The bill permitted police the power to seize assets, such as homes, cars and cash, following drug-related arrests. \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Congress passed the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Anti-Drug Abuse Act","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.ojp.gov/ncjrs/virtual-library/abstracts/anti-drug-abuse-act-1986"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", establishing harsh mandatory minimum federal sentences for drug offenses, including longer sentences for crack cocaine than for powder cocaine (a disparity which ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"was reduced in 2010 from 100:1 to 18:1","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.vox.com/2021/3/19/22336224/equal-act-cocaine-sentencing-disparity-war-on-drugs"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" but nevertheless remains). Many states followed suit thereafter with their own mandatory minimum sentences at the state level. These laws have had a devastating impact on Black communities in particular, who are more likely to be policed, arrested, and sentenced. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Presidential candidate George H. W. Bush widely publicized the case of ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Willie Horton","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/03/us/politics/bush-willie-horton.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", a Black man who, while released from prison on furlough, raped a white woman and killed her boyfriend. Bush used the incident to posture as “tough on crime,” igniting a race between both parties to embrace racist, punitive policies.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The first ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"“three strikes” legislation","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cga.ct.gov/2009/rpt/2009-R-0006.htm#:~:text=Washington%20passed%20the%20first%20three,a%20wide%20range%20of%20felonies.&text=The%20prisoner%2C%20Stevan%20Dozier%2C%20had,times%20of%20second%20degree%20robbery."}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" passed in Washington state, mandating life without parole for defendants convicted three separate times of a felony. Many states followed suit with similarly punitive “three strikes” sentencing laws.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

timelineSections.title: Broken Windows, Surveillance, and Police Brutality
timelineSections.headline: Broken Windows, Surveillance, and Police Brutality

description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The article “","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Broken Windows","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1982/03/broken-windows/304465/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"” was published by two academics in The Atlantic, theorizing that small crimes, left unaddressed, lead to violence, disorder, and broader-scale degradation. The authors argued that petty offenses must be prosecuted in order to prevent mass social disorder. The piece had ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"far-reaching consequences","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2012/03/remembering-broken-windows-co-author-james-q-wilson/331029/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" on law enforcement practices around the country, as police departments adopted “zero tolerance” policies, leading to intensive patrolling and increased arrests, largely in low-income and Black urban neighborhoods.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":" ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Rodney King","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.npr.org/2017/04/26/524744989/when-la-erupted-in-anger-a-look-back-at-the-rodney-king-riots"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", a Black motorist, was pulled over after a car chase and brutally beaten by four police officers in Los Angeles, three of them white. A graphic video of the beating was released to the public, exposing the brutality of the LAPD and igniting a national conversation about racism in policing. When the responsible police officers were acquitted, protests and riots broke out in Los Angeles, resulting in the deaths of 50 people.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Five Black and Hispanic teenage boys -- known as the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Central Park Five","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-48609693"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" -- were wrongly accused and convicted of the rape of a white woman in New York City’s Central Park. Then real estate mogul Donald Trump purchased full page articles in local newspapers calling for the boys to be given the death penalty. \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The FBI launched the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Safe Streets Violent Crime Initiative","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.fbi.gov/investigate/violent-crime/gangs/violent-gang-task-forces"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", which created a series of specialized gang task forces around the country to police, surveil, and prosecute young people suspected of gang involvement, disproportionately young men of color. \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"An academic coined the term “","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"super-predators","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.themarshallproject.org/2020/11/20/superpredator-the-media-myth-that-demonized-a-generation-of-black-youth"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"” in a magazine article, predicting that the nation would see a rising cohort of Black teenage boys who were morally irredeemable and violent juvenile offenders. Though this racist theory was proven false -- juvenile arrests fell during the 1990s and 2000s -- it was a ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"pervasive trope","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.themarshallproject.org/2020/11/20/superpredator-the-media-myth-that-demonized-a-generation-of-black-youth"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that dominated crime stories in the media.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}
